docs.title: Practical High Performance Computing IAP Class
docs.text:
Dates: Tues, Thurs January 21, 23, 28, 30

Time: 2-5pm

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
As part of the Practical Computational Thinking IAP course series, the focus of this workshop is to introduce the role of High Performance Computing (HPC, aka supercomputing) in research. We will discuss the fields where HPC is used and provide concrete examples where we describe the strategies used to scale applications to hundreds of processors. Students will learn when to scale from their laptops to HPC, what challenges that introduces, and how to address those challenges with efficient HPC workflows. Engaging will be used for hands-on examples using C/C++, Julia, Matlab, and/or Python. We will also demonstrate applications using other computing resources on campus, such as the Satori and SuperCloud clusters. Students should bring an existing research problem/application that they would like to scale as a project.

This is a blended course with asynchronous and live components. Much of the lecture is available before class in pre-recorded short videos and class time will be spent on hands-on activities and student research project work.

We will have class on January 21, 23, 28, 30 (Tuesdays and Thursdays) from 2-5pm. The class session topics are as follows:

  • Day 1: Introduction to Supercomputing Workflows and Systems
  • Day 2: Serial Optimization and Parallel Speedup
  • Day 3: Building and Running Parallel Workflows
  • Day 4: Distributed Computing

Prerequisites: Working knowledge of one programming/scripting language. Laptop for hands-on exercises. Participants will get further instruction on how to access Engaging once registered for the class. Students should bring an existing research problem/application that they would like to scale as a project.

docs.title: Asynchronous Lectures and Readings
docs.text:
Review the Asynchronous preparation material for Day 1. (See Checklist below). This material is in the Practical HPC for Engaging Course on the LLx Online course Platform.

Click "Enroll" on the top right. If you already have an account you will be enrolled. If not, you will be taken to a form to create an account. Fill out the form and click "Create your account" to create your account. Keep an eye out for a verification email and verify your account once you've received it. If you don't verify your account, you won't be able to log back in until you do. If you don't get the email, check your junk mailbox.

You should now be able to access the course. We will the assigned modules on this site. These modules must be reviewed before the live session.

In order to complete the exercises you will need an account on Engaging or another similar HPC system. It is best to use the system to plan to use for your research. If you don't have an account you can get one on Engaging by logging into Engaging OnDemand with your Kerberos.

docs.text:
• Enroll in the Practical HPC Course on the LLx Online Course Platform

  • Create an account on Engaging by logging into Engaging OnDemand. You do not need to create an account if you plan to use another similar system for this class, but keep in mind some of the course material may not apply to your system. Course instructors can help where there are differences.
  • Work through the modules:
    • Before you Start
    • Introduction to HPC
    • Introduction to Supercomputing Systems
    • Getting Started with Engaging
  • When instructed in the course:
    • Log into Engaging OnDemand
    • Verify that you can log in via ssh in the terminal on your computer
    • Complete the file transfer exercise: copy your project files to your Engaging account
    • Install any packages or software that you need for your project

docs.title: Project Presentation
docs.text:
In this class we've gone over how to identify the workflow and how to begin scaling out your application based on that workflow. In this presentation we'd like to hear about what you have been able to accomplish on your project up to this point. So we have time for everyone, this should be a ~5 minute presentation with 4-5 slides (slides not required, there will be whiteboards for drawing diagrams/plots if needed). Let us know:

  • Give a general description of your application and your workflow.
    • Your project description should be a brief high-level explanation for a general audience.
  • What technology are you using (or planning to use) to scale out?
  • What have you done so far?
  • What challenges have you come across, or do you anticipate?
  • If it is available, show a scaling curve.

Be sure to cover any challenges or questions that came up during this process. We understand this may take some time depending on your application, so do what you can and let us know what you found out!

You can sign up for a slot on this page (coming soon).

docs.title: Class Description
docs.text:
The focus of this class is to introduce the role of High Performance Computing (HPC, aka supercomputing) in research. We will discuss the fields where HPC is used and provide concrete examples where we describe the strategies used to scale applications to hundreds of processors. Students will learn when to scale from their laptops to HPC, what challenges that introduces, and how to address those challenges with efficient HPC workflows. The MIT SuperCloud will be used for hands-on examples using C/C++, Julia, Matlab, and/or Python. We will also demonstrate applications using other computing resources on campus, such as the Satori and Engaging clusters. Students should bring an existing research problem/application that they would like to scale as a project.

This is a blended course with asynchronous and in-person live components. Much of the lecture will be available before class in pre-recorded short videos and class time will be spent on hands-on activities and student research project work. Students taking the class for MIT credit are required to complete a short report and presentation on their project.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Where is Supercomputing used? When? Why?
  • Know the differences between desktop/laptop and HPC system/supercomputers.
  • Understand how to identify Supercomputing Workflows, plan for how to scale up, and measure performance.

docs.title: Expectations
docs.text: Students are expected to attend scheduled class sessions and review the associated asynchronous material prior to class. All students are highly encouraged to participate in project activities and give a short presentation on the last day of class.
